sen.j: 熊野古道（くまのこどう）は、熊野三山（熊野本宮大社、熊野速玉大社、熊野那智大社）へと通じる参詣道の総称。
sen.e: Kumanokodo Road (Kumona kodo) is a generic term of pilgrimage routes leading to Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha).
Kumanokodo Road (Kumana kodo) is a generic term of pilgrimage routes leading to Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha).
Kumanokodo Road (Kumana kodo) is a generic term of pilgrimage routes leading to Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha).

sen.j: 熊野古道とは、主に以下の6つの道を指す。
sen.e: Kumanokodo Road mainly refers to the following six pilgrimage routes.
Kumanokodo Road mainly refers to the following six pilgrimage routes.
Kumanokodo Road mainly refers to the following six pilgrimage routes.

sen.j: 多くは、2000年に「熊野参詣道」として国の史跡に指定さた。
sen.e: Most of them were designated as historic sites of Japan, as `Kumano pilgrimage route' in 2000.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Most of them were designated as historic sites of Japan, as `Kumano pilgrimage route' in 2000.
Most of them were designated as historic sites of Japan, as `Kumano pilgrimage route' in 2000.

sen.j: 2004年に「紀伊山地の霊場と参詣道」としてユネスコの世界遺産（文化遺産）として登録されたが、紀伊路は登録されていない。
sen.e: In 2004, Kumanokodo Road was registered as a world heritage site (cultural heritage) of UNESCO, as `Sacred Sites and Pilgrimage Routes in the Kii Mountain Range,' but Kiiji route is not registered.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In 2004, Kumanokodo Road was registered as a world heritage site (cultural heritage) of UNESCO, as `Sacred Sites and Pilgrimage Routes in the Kii Mountain Range,' but Kiiji route is not registered.
In 2004, Kumanokodo Road was registered as a world heritage site (cultural heritage) of UNESCO, as `Sacred Sites and Pilgrimage Routes in the Kii Mountain Range,' but Kiiji route is not registered.

sen.j: なお、これは「サンティアゴ・デ・コンポステーラの巡礼路」（スペイン）と共に珍しい道の世界遺産である。
sen.e: It is a rare example of roads which have been registered as a word heritage site, along with ` Way of St. James' (Spain).
It is a rare example of roads which have been registered as a word heritage site, along with ` Way of St. James' (Spain).
It is a rare example of roads which have been registered as a word heritage site, along with ` Way of St. James' (Spain).

sen.j: 紀伊路（渡辺津-田辺）
sen.e: Kiiji route (from Watanabe no tsu to Tanabe)
Kiiji route (from Watanabe no tsu to Tanabe)
Kiiji route (from Watanabe no tsu to Tanabe)

sen.j: 小辺路（高野山-熊野三山、約70km）
sen.e: Kohechi (from Koya-san Mountain to Kumano Sanzan [three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha], approximately 70 kilometers)
Kohechi (from Koya-san Mountain to Kumano Sanzan [three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha], approximately 70 kilometers)
Kohechi (from Koya-san Mountain to Kumano Sanzan [three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha], approximately 70 kilometers)

sen.j: 中辺路（田辺-熊野三山）
sen.e: Nakahechi (from Tanabe to Kumano Sanzan)
Nakahechi (from Tanabe to Kumano Sanzan)
Nakahechi (from Tanabe to Kumano Sanzan)

sen.j: 大辺路（田辺-串本-熊野三山、約120km）
sen.e: Ohechi (from Tanabe to Kushimoto, Kushimoto to Kumano Sanzan, approximately 120 kilometers)
Ohechi (from Tanabe to Kushimoto, Kushimoto to Kumano Sanzan, approximately 120 kilometers)
Ohechi (from Tanabe to Kushimoto, Kushimoto to Kumano Sanzan, approximately 120 kilometers)

sen.j: 伊勢路 (熊野古道)（伊勢神宮-熊野三山、約160km）
sen.e: Ise-ji Route (Kumanokodo Road) (from Ise Jingu Shrine to Kumano Sanzan, approximately 160 kilometers)
Ise-ji Route (Kumanokodo Road) (from Ise Jingu Shrine to Kumano Sanzan, approximately 160 kilometers)
Ise-ji Route (Kumanokodo Road) (from Ise Jingu Shrine to Kumano Sanzan, approximately 160 kilometers)

sen.j: 大峯奥駈道（吉野-前鬼-熊野三山、約140km）
sen.e: Omine Okugake-michi (paths) (from Yoshino to Zenki, zenki to Kumano Sanzan, approximately 140 kilometers)
Omine Okugake-michi (paths) (from Yoshino to Zenki, Zenki to Kumano Sanzan, approximately 140 kilometers)
sen.cmt: zenki to Kumano Sanzan --> Zenki to Kumano Sanzan
sen.e: Omine Okugake-michi (paths) (from Yoshino to Zenki, Zenki to Kumano Sanzan, approximately 140 kilometers)

sen.j: 紀伊半島は、日本でも有数の降雨量の多い地域である。
sen.e: Kii Peninsula is one of regions that have the most rain in Japan.
Kii Peninsula is one of regions that have a large amount of rainfall in Japan.
Kii Peninsula is one of regions that have a large amount of rainfall in Japan.

sen.j: このため、所々に石畳で舗装された道跡が残っている。
sen.e: For this reason, remains of stone pavements are found in spots.
For this reason, remains of stone pavements are found in spots.
For this reason, remains of stone pavements are found in spots.

sen.j: また江戸時代、紀州藩により整備された一里塚が残っている個所もある。
sen.e: Ichirizuka (a milestone between "Ri"s, about 3,927 kilometers), which were developed by the Kishu Domain in the Edo period, are occasionally found.
Ichirizuka (a milestone between "Ri"s, about 3,927 kilometers), which were prepared by the Kishu Domain in the Edo period, are occasionally found.
Ichirizuka (a milestone between "Ri"s, about 3,927 kilometers), which were prepared by the Kishu Domain in the Edo period, are occasionally found.

sen.j: しかし、熊野古道の中には、国道や市街地に吸収されてしまったものもある。
sen.e: However, some Kumanokodo Roads were taken by National Route or urban districts.
However, some Kumanokodo Roads were merged into national routes or urban districts.
However, some Kumanokodo Roads were merged into national routes or urban districts.

sen.j: たとえば、かつて十津川街道として知られていたルートは国道168号線に吸収されている。
sen.e: For instance, the route, which was once known as Totsukawa Road, was taken by National Route 168.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: For instance, the route, which was once known as Totsukawa Road, was merged into National Route 168.
For instance, the route, which was once known as Totsukawa Road, was merged into National Route 168.

sen.j: 紀伊路（大阪-田辺）が登録外であるのも同様の事情による。
sen.e: The reason that Kiiji route (from Osaka to Tanabe) is not registered is due to similar circumstances.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The fact that Kiiji route (from Osaka to Tanabe) is not registered is due to similar circumstances.
The fact that Kiiji route (from Osaka to Tanabe) is not registered is due to similar circumstances.

sen.j: また、登録されたルートでも、大辺路・伊勢路の大部分は国道42号線に吸収されている。
sen.e: Even in terms of routes which have been registered, most of Ohechi and Ise-ji Route were taken by National Route 42.
Even in terms of routes which have been registered, most of Ohechi and Ise-ji Routes are taken by National Route 42.
Even in terms of routes which have been registered, most of Ohechi and Ise-ji Routes are taken by National Route 42.

sen.j: こうしたことが生じるのは、ひとつには紀伊半島の地理による。
sen.e: The geography of Kii Peninsula is one of reasons that made these things happen.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The geography of Kii Peninsula is one of reasons that made these things happen.
The geography of Kii Peninsula is one of reasons that made these things happen.

sen.j: すなわち、紀伊半島の中央部は、際立った高山こそないものの、どこまでも続く山々と谷に覆われている。
sen.e: The central part of Kii Peninsula has no visible high mountains, but is covered in endless mountains and valleys.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The central part of Kii Peninsula has no visibly high mountains, but is covered in endlessly extending mountains and valleys.
sen.cmt: visible high mountains --> visibly high mountains, endless mountains --> endlessly extending mountains
sen.e: The central part of Kii Peninsula has no visibly high mountains, but is covered in endlessly extending mountains and valleys.

sen.j: このため、古来より交通開発が困難であり、交通路が敷かれうる場所も限られていた。
sen.e: For this reason, developing transportation has been difficult since ancient times and areas where traffic routes were developed were limited.
For this reason, development of transportation facilities has been difficult since ancient times and areas for construction of traffic routes were limited.
For this reason, development of transportation facilities has been difficult since ancient times and areas for construction of traffic routes were limited.

sen.j: そのため、小辺路や大峯奥駈道のような例外はあるものの、古人の拓いた道と現在の主要な交通路が、並行（中辺路と国道311号線、JR紀勢本線・国道42号線の紀伊半島部分と大辺路・伊勢路）していることや、重複（前述）していることが少なくないのである。
sen.e: With the exception of roads including Kohechi and Omine Okugake-michi (paths), roads developed by ancient people and current major traffic routes are often paralleled (examples; Nakahechi and National route 311, the part of Kii Peninsula of National route 42 or JR Kisei Main Line and Ohechi and Ise-ji Route) or often overlapped (prescribed earlier).

With the exception of roads including Kohechi and Omine Okugake-michi (paths), roads developed by ancient people and current major traffic routes are often paralleled (examples: Nakahechi and National Route 311; portion of National Route 42 and the JR Kisei Main Line included in Kii Peninsula and Ohechi and Ise-ji Routes) or often overlapped (as prescribed earlier).

With the exception of roads including Kohechi and Omine Okugake-michi (paths), roads developed by ancient people and current major traffic routes are often paralleled (examples: Nakahechi and National Route 311; portion of National Route 42 and the JR Kisei Main Line included in Kii Peninsula and Ohechi and Ise-ji Routes) or often overlapped (as prescribed earlier).

sen.j: また、熊野詣それ自体の盛衰もあって、正確なルートが不明になっている区間があること、歴史的な変遷から生じた派生ルートの扱いなどの問題もある。
sen.e: With rise and decline in popularity of pilgrimages to Kumano Sanzan, adequate routes are unclear in some districts, and the way of handling routes which were derived through historical changes is not fixed.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In addition, with rise and decline in popularity of pilgrimages to Kumano Sanzan, adequate routes are left unclear in some districts, and how to treat the routes derived from historical changes is not fixed.

In addition, with rise and decline in popularity of pilgrimages to Kumano Sanzan, adequate routes are left unclear in some districts, and how to treat the routes derived from historical changes is not fixed.

sen.j: 世界遺産に登録されたものが熊野古道の全てではないことに留意する必要がある。
sen.e: It must be noted that not all the Kumonoko Roads are registered as a world heritage site.
sen.cmt: 一原文・一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: It must be noted that not all the Kumonoko Roads are registered as a world heritage site.
It must be noted that not all the Kumonoko Roads are registered as a world heritage site.

sen.j: また、そうした「忘れられた」ルートを再発見しようとする地元の動きもある。
sen.e: There are some movements to rediscover `the forgotten' routes in local regions.
There are some movements to rediscover `the forgotten' routes by local people.
sen.cmt: in local regions --> by local people
sen.e: There are some movements to rediscover `the forgotten' routes by local people.

sen.j: 熊野周辺は、日本書紀にも登場する自然崇拝の地であった。
sen.e: The area around Kumano, which appeared in Chronicles of Japan, used to be a place of nature worship.
The area around Kumano, which appears in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), used to be a place of nature worship.
sen.cmt: 日本書紀は初出なので"Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan)と表現
sen.e: The area around Kumano, which appears in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), used to be a place of nature worship.

sen.j: 907年の宇多天皇の熊野行幸が最初と言われる。
sen.e: It is said that the first visit to Kumano was the visit by Emperor Uda in 907.
It is said that the first visit to Kumano was the visit by Emperor Uda in 907.
It is said that the first visit to Kumano was the visit by Emperor Uda in 907.

sen.j: 熊野三山への参詣が頻繁に行われるようになったきっかけは、1090年の白河上皇の熊野行幸からと言われている。
sen.e: It is said that Kumano Sanzan came to be frequently visited after a visit to Kumano by the retired Emperor Shirakawa was made in 1090.
It is said that Kumano Sanzan came to be frequently visited after a visit to Kumano by the retired Emperor Shirakawa was made in 1090.
It is said that Kumano Sanzan came to be frequently visited after a visit to Kumano by the retired Emperor Shirakawa was made in 1090.

sen.j: 白河上皇はその後あわせて9回の熊野行幸を行った。
sen.e: After that, the retired Emperor Shirakawa made visits to Kumano nine times in total.
After that, the retired Emperor Shirakawa made visits to Kumano nine times in total.
After that, the retired Emperor Shirakawa made visits to Kumano nine times in total.

sen.j: これにより京都の貴族の間に熊野詣が行われるようになった。
sen.e: The pilgrimage to Kumano Sanzan among court nobles came to be common in Kyoto after this.
The pilgrimage to Kumano Sanzan among court nobles came to be common in Kyoto after this.
The pilgrimage to Kumano Sanzan among court nobles came to be common in Kyoto after this.

sen.j: その後、後白河上皇も33回の熊野行幸を行っている。
sen.e: The retired Emperor Goshirakawa also visited Kumano 33 times in total.
The retired Emperor Goshirakawa also visited Kumano 33 times in total.
The retired Emperor Goshirakawa also visited Kumano 33 times in total.

sen.j: 江戸時代に入ると、伊勢詣と並び、熊野詣は、広く庶民が行うようになったといわれている。
sen.e: After the Edo Period, a pilgrimage to Kumano Sanzan became popular among common people, along with a pilgrimage to Ise.
In the Edo Period, a pilgrimage to Kumano Sanzan became popular among common people, along with a pilgrimage to Ise.
sen.cmt: After the Edo Period --> In the Edo Period
sen.e: In the Edo Period, a pilgrimage to Kumano Sanzan became popular among common people, along with a pilgrimage to Ise.

sen.j: 一時は、熊野付近の旅籠に1日で800人の宿泊が記録されたこともあったようだ。
sen.e: At one time, it seems that 800 travelers stayed in hatago (inn with meals) in the vicinity of Kumano in a day.
At one time, it seems that 800 travelers stayed in hatago (inn with meals) in the vicinity of Kumano in a day.
At one time, it seems that 800 travelers stayed in hatago (inn with meals) in the vicinity of Kumano in a day.

sen.j: 明治維新後、神仏分離令により熊野古道周辺の神社の数は激減。
sen.e: After the Maiji Restoration, the number of shrines around Kumanokodo Road dropped significantly.
After the Maiji Restoration, the number of shrines around Kumanokodo Road dropped significantly.
After the Maiji Restoration, the number of shrines around Kumanokodo Road dropped significantly.

sen.j: 熊野詣の風習も殆どなくなってしまった。
sen.e: The custom of pilgrimage to Kumano died out.
The custom of pilgrimage to Kumano almost died out.
The custom of pilgrimage to Kumano almost died out.

sen.j: 熊野古道自体は、大正から昭和にかけて国道が整備されるまで、周囲の生活道路として使用されつづけた。
sen.e: Kumanokodo Road itself had been used until national routes were developed, from the Taisho Period through until the Showa Period, as a community road in the neighborhood.
Kumanokodo Road itself had been used as a community road for the neighborhood people until national routes were developed from the Taisho Period through the Showa Period.
Kumanokodo Road itself had been used as a community road for the neighborhood people until national routes were developed from the Taisho Period through the Showa Period.

tit.e: Kujuku Oji (A series of Shrines which were established from 12 century to 13 century by the Kumano Shugen priests.)
Kujuku Oji (A series of Shrines which were established from 12 century to 13 century by the Kumano Shugen priests.)
Kujuku Oji (A series of Shrines which were established from 12 century to 13 century by the Kumano Shugen priests.)

sen.j: 熊野古道（特に紀伊路、中辺路）には大阪の基点であった淀川河口の渡辺津（窪津、九品津）から熊野三山までに100近くの熊野権現を祭祀した九十九王子があった。
sen.e: In Kumanokodo Road (especially in Kiiji route and in Nakahechi), there was Kujuku Oji, where nearly 100 Kumano Gongen were worshipped, extending from Watanabe-no-tsu (Kubotsu, Kubotsu) at the mouth of Yodogawa-rover, the base of Osaka to Kumano Sanzan

In Kumanokodo Road (especially in Kiiji route and in Nakahechi), there was Kujuku Oji, where nearly 100 Kumano Gongen were worshipped, extending from Watanabe-no-tsu (Kubotsu, Kubotsu) at the mouth of Yodogawa-river, the base of Osaka to Kumano Sanzan.

In Kumanokodo Road (especially in Kiiji route and in Nakahechi), there was Kujuku Oji, where nearly 100 Kumano Gongen were worshipped, extending from Watanabe-no-tsu (Kubotsu, Kubotsu) at the mouth of Yodogawa-river, the base of Osaka to Kumano Sanzan.

sen.j: 現存するものは少ない。
sen.e: Only few sacred places are remained.
Few sacred places remain today.
Few sacred places remain today.
